title: Cieren Fallon interview: His belated racing interest, living with a famous name and closing in on a feat his father never achieved
text:
All things being equal, Cieren Fallon will be crowned champion apprentice jockey at Ascot’s Qipco British Champions Day on Saturday, a remarkable feat given that, despite his name and racing heritage, he had never sat on a horse until two years ago.

When he surprised his family by announcing his intention to be a jockey, his father, Kieren, brought him to Newmarket and, before enrolling him for the British Racing School, took him to sit on a pony at the farm of fellow jockey Adam Kirby.

“Can you feel it? Can you feel it?” asked an expectant Fallon Snr, hoping his son had instantly connected to that invisible string through which flows the indefinable understanding between horse and jockey. “Feel what, Dad?” replied the son.

If he was not feeling it then, he is now.

This time 12 months ago, Fallon Jnr had just ridden his first winner. Now he is one shy of a half-century of winners for the turf season, and has a lead of seven over title rival Sean Davis going into the last five days of the season.
